snippet.title: Right and Wrong
snippet.description:
Join us (almost) every night at 9 PM Eastern time. We are currently meeting in Second Life ( http://www.secondlife.com/ ) at the Buddha Center.

You can also listen live at http://sirimangalo.org:8000/live or find archived mp3s awt http://static.sirimangalo.org/diraudio/Yuttadhammo/Live/

- - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - -

Our Website:

http://www.sirimangalo.org/

- - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - -

Subscribe for updates here:

http://www.youtube.com/subscription_center?add_user=yuttadhammo

and don't forget to click the 'like' button to help promote these videos!  Thanks for your questions, comments and support for what I do.

May all beings be happy.

snippet.title: What Meditation Is Not
snippet.description: A short cautionary note on dealing with "special" states encountered in meditation.  The answer is to understand that there is no state that should be judged as more special than another, but simply to see and acknowledge everything as it is, for what it is.

snippet.title: Ajaan Tong Opening Discourse on Four Foundations of Mindfulness
snippet.description:
This is a talk I found on YouTube in four parts uploaded by this user:

http://www.youtube.com/user/toudhammavedio

The talk was given as part of Ajaan Tong's discourse to the leaders of the Thai monastic community who had assembled for a special course in insight meditation.  I have put the videos together, cleaned up the audio a bit and added subtitles (use the CC button to access the subtitles).

Ajaan Tong (Phra Dhammamangalajaan Vi.) is my teacher and preceptor, and a student of the late Venerable Mahasi Sayadaw.

snippet.description:
A morning session on Second Life ( http://www.secondlife.com ) at the Buddha Center ( http://www.thebuddhacenter.org ) talking about ways of discerning what is and what is not the Buddha's teaching.

I teach in Second Life on Sundays at 3 PM and Wednesdays at 9 AM.

snippet.title: Sirimangalo Int'l Presents: David Holmes
snippet.description:
Sirimangalo Int'l Presents: David Holmes

Sirimangalo Int'l Presents is our new weekly guest series where we talk to interesting people in the global Buddhist community.

In this episode we talk with David Holmes, a long-time Buddhist scholar and meditator in the Theravada tradition about his life and experience on the Buddhist path.

snippet.title: Sirimangalo Int'l Presents: Ali Ashtari
snippet.description:
Sirimangalo Int'l Presents: Ali Ashtari

Premier of our new weekly guest series, talking to fellow Buddhist meditator and teacher, Ali Ashtari, about meditation, skepticism, atheists, and Iran.

snippet.title: Dhamma Group
snippet.description:
A recording of our first ever live on-line Dhamma Group!  Here's the announcement:

Today we will officially begin our weekly live Dhamma Group with audio and video via Google+ Hangouts.  The meeting starts at 2 PM UTC and will go until it's finished.  The proposed schedule is as follows:

1. Dhamma Friends - let us know about yourself
2. Dhamma Recital - taking refuge and precepts
3. Dhamma Sharing - sharing something with the group (optional)
4. Dhamma Study - taking turns reading from a dhamma text
5. Dhamma Practice - group meditation practice


How To Join?
===========

Join by visiting my Google+ profile (https://plus.google.com/118014954414967440482/posts) and looking for the Hangout post, subject to the following restrictions:

Only ten people can join the group at one time.  This is a technical limit imposed by Google, but probably well and good, since it will keep the group manageable.  It does mean, obviously, that space is limited to whoever joins first, except...

You need to be in my circles to join the group.  Given the limited number of seats, and in order to make it most productive, I'm hoping to limit participation to people who have a genuine interest in the Buddha's teaching and not likely to cause a disturbance to the group.  If you would like to join, please send me a message via Google+ telling me what you think you could bring to the group, and I'll add people to my circles as seems appropriate.

You need a webcam, a microphone and a fast Internet connection to participate.  Again, given the limited space, I'm going to impose this as a restriction - please don't join the hangout if you just want to listen, because...

If you can't join due to any of the limitations above, don't fret; the Dhamma Group will be broadcast live via my YouTube channel (http://www.youtube.come/yuttadhammo), so you can head on over there and join at least passively.  I know some people were reluctant about the idea of broadcasting to YouTube, but it seems the only way to realistically accommodate the number of people interested in this idea.

So, come one, come all, let's join together in sharing and spreading the dhamma.


Dates and Times
=============

Date: every Saturday (that's today!)

Time: 2 PM UTC

Local Times:

Los Angeles: 7 AM
New York: 10 AM
London: 3 PM
Colombo: 7:30 PM
Tokyo: 11 PM

I'm going to try to be early, so if you really want to join, please try to be early as well so we can get settled before the broadcast!

snippet.title: Unshaken
snippet.description:
To ask questions and join our community, please visit http://meditation.sirimangalo.org/
To support our work, please visit http://www.sirimangalo.org/support/

Dhammatalk on the eight loka­dhamma: gain (lābho), loss (alābho), popularity (yaso), unpopularity (ayaso), blame (nindā), praise (pasaṃsā), happiness (sukha), suffering (dukkha).

Re-upload of dhammatalk from June 16, 2018.

Here is a discourse on the worldly vicissitudes by Mahāsi Sayādaw: http://www.aimwell.org/lokadhamma.html.

.

snippet.title: Swastika - Bringers of Well-being
snippet.description:
On the things that bring (ika) well-being (sva+asti = svasti) = swastika.

Swastika is a Sanskrit word that has nothing intrinsically to do with Nazi Germany.  The Pali equivalent is 'sovatthika' (su + atthi + ṇika) and is a name for certain qualities in the Buddha's teaching.

snippet.title: Monk Radio, Nov. 9, 2014
snippet.description:
Questions:

10:24 Question 1: What is access concentration? Do I need to attain access concentration or any other state of concentration before I practice insight meditation?

19:19 Question 2: In your last video you said that when a layperson becomes an Arahat, he or she will probably pass away. What do you mean by that? 

32:30 Question 3: When I do sitting meditation I sometimes have a rocking motion / loss of balance, and that sensation is so intense that I jump, and my heart is accelerating. What can I do when I meditate in a quiet place if I hear a sound ,for example: a ringing telephone, and I jump too?

52:23 cont. Question 3: I just want to precise some point. It is not a continuous rocking motion, it’s like standing on one foot and you lose your balance. It’s a sensation of falling. And even in real life I jump too when a hear a sudden sound.

37:32 Question 4: What was your experience like while simultaneously attending university and being a monk. Would it be possible for one to be an Anagarika while continuing their eduction? 

49:22 Question 5: I find meditation difficult as I suffer from tinnitus. When I sit in a quiet room, and try to rid myself of distractions, a high pitched noise seems to take over. Is it possible with practice to overcome this noise?

56:04 Are monks advised not to read fiction books? I’ve seen in some videos where you mentioned books such as ‘crime and punishment’ and ‘hitchhikers guide to the galaxy’. Did you read these before you became a monk? 

58:10 While doing sitting meditation my spine is straight and my upper body muscles are relaxed. My ribcage starts to feel heavy, and pushing against my lungs, so it feels a bit difficult to breathe. Should I observe this, or fix my position somehow? 

1:00:22 While sitting in meditation a tree branch touches my head. Should I move mindfully, or note the touching?

snippet.title: Monk Radio: Nov. 1, 2014
snippet.description:
Question:

3:18 Robin introduces herself

4:58 Yuttadhammo introduces himself 

11:09 Yuttadhammo on doing (a) meditation (course) while using medication or psychoactive drugs

19:57 Question 1: I have schizophrenia. When off medication I experience great suffering with voices which lead to delusion and even greater stress. Is there real hope for resolution with meditative practice?

32:23 Question 2: Is lay Buddhism just a kind of compromise for those who arent capable of monastic life? And how do those who have responsibilities they can’t forgo, like children, integrate the Buddhist teaching into their lives? 

38:26 Question 3: What are your views on homosexuality? And is Buddhism for it, or against it?

1:09:54 Question 4: What are your views on the zen idea of not trying to achieve anything? 

1:30:42 Question 5: How can you say that the body is not natural?

snippet.description:

This clip, an addendum to the series on how to meditate, attempts to answer two reoccurring questions in meditation practice; one on the method itself and one on the results to be expected. (orig. publ. 10 Oct 2013)

snippet.title: Dhammapada 1:  Suffering is Mind-made
snippet.description:
To ask questions and join our community, please visit http://meditation.sirimangalo.org/
To support our work, please visit http://www.sirimangalo.org/support/

Verse 1 in Pāḷi: Yamaka

Manopubbaṅgamā dhammā, 
manoseṭṭhā manomayā,
manasā ce paduṭṭhena 
bhāsati vā karoti vā,
tato naṁ dukkham anveti 
cakkaṁ va vahato padaṁ.

The background story can be found here:
https://what-buddha-said.net/Canon/Sutta/KN/Dhammapada.Verse_1.story.htm

Re-upload of video on Dhammapada verse 1, from Aug 6, 2011.

.

snippet.title: Dhammapada 2: Happiness is Mind-made
snippet.description:
To ask questions and join our community, please visit http://meditation.sirimangalo.org/
To support our work, please visit http://www.sirimangalo.org/support/

Verse 2 in Pāḷi 2: Yamaka

manopubbaṅgamā dhammā,
manoseṭṭhā manomayā,
manasā ce pasannena
bhāsati vā karoti vā,
tato naṁ sukham anveti
chāyā va anapāyinī.

The background story can be found here:
https://what-buddha-said.net/Canon/Sutta/KN/Dhammapada.htm#Twin%20Pairs%20-%20Yamaka

Re-upload of video on Dhammapada verse 1, from Aug 7, 2011.

snippet.title: Dhammapada Verses Three and Four: Clinging to Perceived Wrongs Only Leads to More Wrong
snippet.description:
akkocchi maṃ avadhi maṃ, ajini maṃ ahāsi me.

ye ca taṃ upanayhanti, veraṃ tesaṃ na sammati.

akkocchi maṃ avadhi maṃ, ajini maṃ ahāsi me.

ye ca taṃ nupanayhanti, veraṃ tesūpasammati.

Video #3 in my series on the Dhammapada, a set of verse teachings of the Buddha, including explanation of the Pali verse, a synopsis of the background story and application of the teaching to our practice.

snippet.title: Dhammapada Verses Seven & Eight: A Weak Tree and a Mountain of Solid Rock
snippet.description:
subhānupassiṃ viharantaṃ, indriyesu asaṃvutaṃ.

bhojanamhi cāmattaññuṃ, kusītaṃ hīnavīriyaṃ.

taṃ ve pasahati māro, vāto rukkhaṃva dubbalaṃ.


asubhānupassiṃ viharantaṃ, indriyesu susaṃvutaṃ.

bhojanamhi ca mattaññuṃ, saddhaṃ āraddhavīriyaṃ.

taṃ ve nappasahati māro, vāto selaṃva pabbataṃ.

snippet.title: Dhammapada Verses Nine and Ten: Worthy of the Robe
snippet.description:
anikkasāvo kāsāvaṃ, yo vatthaṃ paridahissati.
apeto damasaccena, na so kāsāvamarahati.

yo ca vantakasāvassa, sīlesu susamāhito.
upeto damasaccena, sa ve kāsāvamarahati.

snippet.description:
asāre sāramatino, sāre cāsāradassino.
te sāraṃ nādhigacchanti, micchāsaṅkappagocarā.

sārañca sārato ñatvā, asārañca asārato.
te sāraṃ adhigacchanti, sammāsaṅkappagocarā.

snippet.title: Dhammapada Verses 13 and 14: A Well-Thatched Roof
snippet.description:
yathā agāraṁ ducchannaṁ, vuṭṭhī samativijjhati.
evaṁ abhāvitaṁ cittaṁ, rāgo samativijjhati.

yathā agāraṁ suchannaṁ, vuṭṭhī na samativijjhati.
evaṁ subhāvitaṁ cittaṁ, rāgo na samativijjhati.

snippet.title: Dhammapada Verses 19 and 20: Who Partakes in the Fruit
snippet.description:
bahumpi ce saṁhita bhāsamāno, na takkaro hoti naro pamatto.
gopova gāvo gaṇayaṁ paresaṁ, na bhāgavā sāmaññassa hoti.

appampi ce saṁhita bhāsamāno, dhammassa hoti anudhammacārī.
rāgañca dosañca pahāya mohaṁ, sammappajāno suvimuttacitto.
anupādiyāno idha vā huraṁ vā, sa bhāgavā sāmaññassa hoti.

snippet.title: Dhammapada Verses 21, 22, and 23: The Mindful Never Die
snippet.description:
21. appamādo amatapadaṁ, pamādo maccuno padaṁ.
appamattā na mīyanti, ye pamattā yathā matā.

22. evaṁ visesato ñatvā, appamādamhi paṇḍitā.
appamāde pamodanti, ariyānaṁ gocare ratā.

23. te jhāyino sātatikā, niccaṁ daḷhaparakkamā.
phusanti dhīrā nibbānaṁ, yogakkhemaṁ anuttaraṁ.

snippet.title: Dhammapada Verses 38 & 39: Settling the Mind
snippet.description:
38. anavaṭṭhitacittassa, saddhammaṃ avijānato.
pariplavapasādassa, paññā na paripūrati.

39. anavassutacittassa, ananvāhatacetaso.
puññapāpapahīnassa, natthi jāgarato bhayaṃ.

snippet.title: Dhammapada Verse 42: Worse Than An Enemy
snippet.description:
42. diso disaṃ yaṃ taṃ kayirā, verī vā pana verinaṃ.
micchāpaṇihitaṃ cittaṃ, pāpiyo naṃ tato kare.

Whatever harm an enemy may do to an enemy, or a hater to a hater, an ill-directed mind inflicts on oneself a greater harm.

snippet.title: Dhammapada Verse 43: Better Than A Blood-Relative
snippet.description:
43. na taṃ mātā pitā kayirā, aññe vāpi ca ñātakā.
sammāpaṇihitaṃ cittaṃ, seyyaso naṃ tato kare.

Neither mother, father, nor any other relative can do one 
greater good than one's own well-directed mind.

Video 31 in a series on the Dhammapada, a set of 423 verse teachings given by the Buddha, including explanation of the Pali verse, a synopsis of the background story and application of the teaching to our practice.

snippet.title: Dhammapada Verses 44 & 45: Overcome the World
snippet.description:
44. ko imaṃ pathaviṃ vicessati, yamalokañca imaṃ sadevakaṃ.
ko dhammapadaṃ sudesitaṃ, kusalo pupphamiva pacessati .

45. sekho pathaviṃ vicessati, yamalokañca imaṃ sadevakaṃ.
sekho dhammapadaṃ sudesitaṃ, kusalo pupphamiva pacessati.

Video 32 in a series on the Dhammapada, a set of 423 verse teachings given by the Buddha, including explanation of the Pali verse, a synopsis of the background story and application of the teaching to our practice.

etesaṃ gandhajātānaṃ, sīlagandho anuttaro.

na so saṅkhātadhammānaṃ, kalaṃ agghati soḷasiṃ.

snippet.title: Dhammapada Verses 73 & 74: Ambition and Conceit
snippet.description:

mamevātivasā assu, kiccākiccesu kismici.
iti bālassa saṅkappo, icchā māno ca vaḍḍhati.

snippet.title: Dhammapada Verses 87-89: Brilliant
snippet.description:
87. “kaṇhaṃ dhammaṃ vippahāya, sukkaṃ bhāvetha paṇḍito.
okā anokamāgamma, viveke yattha dūramaṃ.

88. “tatrābhiratimiccheyya, hitvā kāme akiñcano.
pariyodapeyya attānaṃ, cittaklesehi paṇḍito.

89. “yesaṃ sambodhiyaṅgesu, sammā cittaṃ subhāvitaṃ.
ādānapaṭinissagge, anupādāya ye ratā.
khīṇāsavā jutimanto, te loke parinibbutā”ti.

Part of a series on the Dhammapada, a set of 423 verse teachings given by the Buddha, including explanation of the Pali verse, a synopsis of the background story and application of the teaching to our practice.

snippet.title: Dhammapada Verse 90: Distress
snippet.description:

snippet.title: Dhammapada Verse 107: A Better Moment
snippet.description:
107. yo ca vassasataṃ jantu, aggiṃ paricare vane.
ekañca bhāvitattānaṃ, muhuttamapi pūjaye.
sāyeva pūjanā seyyo, yañce vassasataṃ hutaṃ.

Part of a series on the Dhammapada, a set of 423 verse teachings given by the Buddha, including explanation of the Pali verse, a synopsis of the background story and application of the teaching to our practice.

snippet.title: Dhammapada vv. 119 and 120: Ripening
snippet.description:
119. pāpopi passati bhadraṃ, yāva pāpaṃ na paccati.
yadā ca paccati pāpaṃ, atha pāpo pāpāni passati.

120. bhadropi passati pāpaṃ, yāva bhadraṃ na paccati.
yadā ca paccati bhadraṃ, atha bhadro bhadrāni passati.

snippet.title: Dhammapada Verse 127: No Escape
snippet.description:

na vijjatī so jagatippadeso, yatthaṭṭhito mucceyya pāpakammā.

snippet.description:

snippet.title: Dhammapada Verses 131 & 132: Seeking Happiness
snippet.description:
131. sukhakāmāni bhūtāni, yo daṇḍena vihiṃsati.
attano sukhamesāno, pecca so na labhate sukhaṃ.

132. sukhakāmāni bhūtāni, yo daṇḍena na hiṃsati.
attano sukhamesāno, pecca so labhate sukhaṃ.

snippet.title: Dhammapada Verses 133 & 134: A Broken Gong
snippet.description:
133. māvoca pharusaṃ kañci, vuttā paṭivadeyyu taṃ .
dukkhā hi sārambhakathā, paṭidaṇḍā phuseyyu taṃ .

134. sace neresi attānaṃ, kaṃso upahato yathā.
esa pattosi nibbānaṃ, sārambho te na vijjati.

snippet.title: Dhammapada Verses 137-140: Harming the Harmless
snippet.description:
137. yo daṇḍena adaṇḍesu, appaduṭṭhesu dussati.
dasannamaññataraṃ ṭhānaṃ, khippameva nigacchati.

138. vedanaṃ pharusaṃ jāniṃ, sarīrassa ca bhedanaṃ .
garukaṃ vāpi ābādhaṃ, cittakkhepañca pāpuṇe.

139. rājato vā upasaggaṃ, abbhakkhānañca dāruṇaṃ.
parikkhayañca ñātīnaṃ, bhogānañca pabhaṅguraṃ .

140. atha vāssa agārāni, aggi ḍahati pāvako.
kāyassa bhedā duppañño, nirayaṃ sopapajjati .

Part of a series on the Dhammapada, a set of 423 verse teachings given by the Buddha, including explanation of the Pali verse, a synopsis of the background story and application of the teaching to our practice.

snippet.title: A Meditator's Life
snippet.description:
To ask questions and join our community, please visit http://meditation.sirimangalo.org/
To support our work, please visit http://www.sirimangalo.org/support/

This talk is based on the Sabbāsava Sutta and contains guidelines for the daily life of a meditator.

Re-upload of dhammatalk from June 9, 2018.

.

snippet.title: Existence of the Mind: Absolute Ethics
snippet.description: More thoughts on the existence of both mental and material reality, and the implications thereof.  In this video, I discuss the possibility from a scientific point of view of ultimate moral law.

snippet.title: What Meditation Is Not
snippet.description: A short cautionary note on dealing with "special" states encountered in meditation.  The answer is to understand that there is no state that should be judged as more special than another, but simply to see and acknowledge everything as it is, for what it is.

snippet.title: Q&A: Peaceful Meditation
snippet.description:
To ask questions and join our community, please visit http://meditation.sirimangalo.org/
To support our work, please visit http://www.sirimangalo.org/support/

Question in this video:
Could you talk a bit about how mindfulness can be restful? I find a lot that I become distracted and pulled into a sort of comfortable unconscious haze. I’d like to be able to reside in the present throughout my day, though it can be quite exhausting, because mindfulness is a difficult thing. Yet I see spiritual teachers who are very at ease and rested in the present moment. What leads to their ability to do this, and how do I know that I am going in the right direction?

Re-upload of Q&A session by Bhante Yuttadhammo; Dec 26, 2018.

.

snippet.title: Ajaan Tong Opening Discourse on Four Foundations of Mindfulness
snippet.description:
This is a talk I found on YouTube in four parts uploaded by this user:

http://www.youtube.com/user/toudhammavedio

The talk was given as part of Ajaan Tong's discourse to the leaders of the Thai monastic community who had assembled for a special course in insight meditation.  I have put the videos together, cleaned up the audio a bit and added subtitles (use the CC button to access the subtitles).

Ajaan Tong (Phra Dhammamangalajaan Vi.) is my teacher and preceptor, and a student of the late Venerable Mahasi Sayadaw.

snippet.title: Q&A: Short Meditation Sessions
snippet.description:
To ask questions and join our community, please visit http://meditation.sirimangalo.org/
To support our work, please visit http://www.sirimangalo.org/support/

Question in this video:
Is there anything wrong about doing a lot of short sessions? My practice right now is: 10 min of meditation, then 4 min rest, 10 min meditation, then 4 min rest... and so on from morning until evening. Should I do longer session or can I remain like this?

Re-upload of Q&A session by Bhante Yuttadhammo; Dec 23, 2018.

.

snippet.title: The Nature of Reality (Death, Rebirth and Reincarnation)
snippet.description: An explanation of why it is reasonable to discard a belief in death in favor of an understanding of the constant flow of mind and body phenomena that constitutes reality.

snippet.title: Suffering and Experiential Reality
snippet.description:
To ask questions and join our community, please visit http://meditation.sirimangalo.org/
To support our work, please visit http://www.sirimangalo.org/support/

Dhammatalk about the Buddhist principle of suffering and experiential reality.

Re-upload of dhammatalk from June 30, 2018.

.

snippet.title: Explaining the Existence of the Mind
snippet.description: This is a video trying to explain to Westerners why it is easier to believe in the existence of the mind as a separate entity from the body than to believe it simply a product of the brain.

snippet.title: Existence of the Mind Revisited
snippet.description: More thoughts on the existence of both mental and material reality, and the implications thereof.

snippet.title: Existence of the Mind: Absolute Ethics
snippet.description: More thoughts on the existence of both mental and material reality, and the implications thereof.  In this video, I discuss the possibility from a scientific point of view of ultimate moral law.

snippet.title: Existence of the Mind: God and Self
snippet.description: More thoughts on the existence of both mental and material reality, and the implications thereof.  In this video, I discuss the incompatibility between the existence of a nature-governed mind and the existence of a self or god.

snippet.title: Ask A Monk: What the Buddha Didn't Teach

snippet.title: Q&A: Mindfulness and Noting
snippet.description:
To ask questions and join our community, please visit http://meditation.sirimangalo.org/
To support our work, please visit http://www.sirimangalo.org/support/

Question in this video:
Can multiple meditation objects form a single object that can be noted? For example, I suffer from fairly severe anxiety. During meditation, when I try to note the anxiety, I find that the feeling of anxiety coincides with repetitive thoughts about the things that bring me anxiety. I note both the thinking and the feeling of anxiety as a single meditation object and say to myself "anxious, anxious..." Is this incorrect practice? I struggle to understand how the mind handles the different components of reality. It seems like while the mind is aware of one component, it also has a "background awareness" of the other components since we are able to divert our attention to any of the other components. If this is the case, couldn't we just note all objects at once? Furthermore, is there any relationship between numbers and absolute reality? If the mind can only be aware of one thing at once, is the number 1 the only number that exists? Clarification would be greatly appreciated. Thank you.

Re-upload of Q&A session by Bhante Yuttadhammo; May 13, 2019.

.

snippet.title: Q&A: Noting and Clinging
snippet.description:
To ask questions and join our community, please visit http://meditation.sirimangalo.org/
To support our work, please visit http://www.sirimangalo.org/support/

Question in this video:
I've been using the 5 aggregates to note experiences I have during meditation, an itch is noted as form/feeling, thought of work/family as formation, etc, obviously, all experiences are developed through multiple aggregates, but, would you think that this noting technique could encourage clinging to the aggregates rather than helping observe their impermanence?  Also, while using this technique, they are always connected to a hindrance/fetter, which quickly makes it apparent that all experience is wrapped in hindrance/fetter, I know this exhibits the hindrance of doubt, but, this seems short sighted?

Re-upload of Q&A session by Bhante Yuttadhammo; June 8, 2019.

.

contentDetails.note: Re-upload of q&a session by Bhante Yuttadhammo; June 8, 2019.

snippet.title: Q&A: Mindfulness and Noting
snippet.description:
To ask questions and join our community, please visit http://meditation.sirimangalo.org/
To support our work, please visit http://www.sirimangalo.org/support/

Question in this video:
Can multiple meditation objects form a single object that can be noted? For example, I suffer from fairly severe anxiety. During meditation, when I try to note the anxiety, I find that the feeling of anxiety coincides with repetitive thoughts about the things that bring me anxiety. I note both the thinking and the feeling of anxiety as a single meditation object and say to myself "anxious, anxious..." Is this incorrect practice? I struggle to understand how the mind handles the different components of reality. It seems like while the mind is aware of one component, it also has a "background awareness" of the other components since we are able to divert our attention to any of the other components. If this is the case, couldn't we just note all objects at once? Furthermore, is there any relationship between numbers and absolute reality? If the mind can only be aware of one thing at once, is the number 1 the only number that exists? Clarification would be greatly appreciated. Thank you.

Re-upload of Q&A session by Bhante Yuttadhammo; May 13, 2019.

.

snippet.title: Ask A Monk: Criticism and Insults
snippet.description:
"I have a fear of connecting to people. Harsh criticisms or dirty looks seem to cripple me. When a person insults me, or if I feel someone is angry with me, I lose all energy and I really do feel deeply cut. Do you have any advice?"

Please submit questions to my YouTube Channel: http://www.youtube.com/yuttadhammo

and subscribe for updates here:

http://www.youtube.com/subscription_center?add_user=yuttadhammo

snippet.title: Q&A: Noting and Clinging
snippet.description:
To ask questions and join our community, please visit http://meditation.sirimangalo.org/
To support our work, please visit http://www.sirimangalo.org/support/

Question in this video:
I've been using the 5 aggregates to note experiences I have during meditation, an itch is noted as form/feeling, thought of work/family as formation, etc, obviously, all experiences are developed through multiple aggregates, but, would you think that this noting technique could encourage clinging to the aggregates rather than helping observe their impermanence?  Also, while using this technique, they are always connected to a hindrance/fetter, which quickly makes it apparent that all experience is wrapped in hindrance/fetter, I know this exhibits the hindrance of doubt, but, this seems short sighted?

Re-upload of Q&A session by Bhante Yuttadhammo; June 8, 2019.

.

contentDetails.note: Re-upload of q&a session by Bhante Yuttadhammo; June 8, 2019.

snippet.title: Q&A: Meditation and Intense Emotions
snippet.description:
To ask questions and join our community, please visit http://meditation.sirimangalo.org/
To support our work, please visit http://www.sirimangalo.org/support/

Question in this video:
How does one cope with strong attachments to one's life partner, and feeling frustration and sadness for being forced to live apart for months? I am very much attached to my fiancé and cant get seem to be able to have a peaceful meditation practice when he is away for so long. What should I do? Thank you kindly.

The video Bhante refers to in the answer is the video "Ask a Monk: Experience of Reality". It can be found here:
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=fjUkzRcNhK8&t=0s&list=PL4j9bs3T1aPT2KP67K287cWvN3-SsCPhk&index=14

Re-upload of Q&A session by Bhante Yuttadhammo; Dec 25, 2018.

.

snippet.title: Q&A: Dealing With the Effects of Meditation
snippet.description:
To ask questions and join our community, please visit http://meditation.sirimangalo.org/
To support our work, please visit http://www.sirimangalo.org/support/

Question in this video:
After I do meditation in the afternoon I go out of my room and I take food with some people but I have notice that I have a lot of concentration and they tell me I look like if I'm on drugs and I tried to be "normal" but if I talk my head starts to hurt and I start to shake like a bell and I have a lot of sweating, especially in the hands and this is everyday and I'm kind of embarrassed, in general is difficult to deal with people after I meditate but I don't think going to a cave is a solution... any recommendation? Thanks!

Re-upload of Q&A session by Bhante Yuttadhammo; Dec 24, 2018.

.

snippet.title: First Stage in Meditation: Understanding Body And Mind
snippet.description:
This video is a simple explanation on the beginning stage of insight knowledge that arises based on meditation practice as explained in my videos on how to meditate.

Please note that this video is for those who are actively undertaking the practice of meditation as taught at

http://www.youtube.com/view_play_list?p=603BD0B03E12F5A1 

and should not be used as a substitute for a qualified teacher.  If you would like advice and guidance in your meditation practice, please contact me via Youtube or Skype (username: yuttadhammo)

Please submit questions to my YouTube Channel: 

http://www.youtube.com/yuttadhammo

and subscribe for updates here:

http://www.youtube.com/subscription_center?add_user=yuttadhammo

snippet.title: Second Life: White Supremacy
snippet.description: An afternoon session on Second Life ( http://www.secondlife.com ) at the Buddha Center ( http://www.thebuddhacenter.org ) talking about white and black in Buddhism and overcoming good and evil.

snippet.title: Buddhist Explanation of Karma
snippet.description:
Detailed explanation of karma (kamma) according to Theravada Buddhism:

- How karma works on a momentary level
- The different type of effect karma can have
- The order in which different karmas have an effect
- When karma will have an effect
- How karma is actually a practical teaching, not a theoretical one

snippet.title: Q&A: Avoidance of Someone Who Betrayed You
snippet.description:
To ask questions and join our community, please visit http://meditation.sirimangalo.org/
To support our work, please visit http://www.sirimangalo.org/support/

Question in this video:
Dear Bhante, a friend of mine betrayed me. It bothered me so much that affecting my meditation practices. I'm new to meditation (but I'm trying to do it regularly now), so I'm still having trouble letting go. Would it be wise to avoid this person until my practice is stronger and I can let completely go this person? Thank you.

New re-upload of Q&A session by Bhante Yuttadhammo; April 28, 2019.

.

contentDetails.note: New re-upload; streamed live on Apr 28, 2019.

snippet.title: Explaining the Existence of the Mind
snippet.description: This is a video trying to explain to Westerners why it is easier to believe in the existence of the mind as a separate entity from the body than to believe it simply a product of the brain.

snippet.title: Existence of the Mind Revisited
snippet.description: More thoughts on the existence of both mental and material reality, and the implications thereof.

snippet.title: Existence of the Mind: Absolute Ethics
snippet.description: More thoughts on the existence of both mental and material reality, and the implications thereof.  In this video, I discuss the possibility from a scientific point of view of ultimate moral law.

snippet.title: Existence of the Mind: God and Self
snippet.description: More thoughts on the existence of both mental and material reality, and the implications thereof.  In this video, I discuss the incompatibility between the existence of a nature-governed mind and the existence of a self or god.

snippet.title: Ask A Monk: Buddhist Funerals and Relating Conversion
snippet.description:
"I come from a very Irish Catholic family but i consider myself to be a Buddhist and have for the past few years. I feel i need to let my friends and family know for the fact that if i was to suddenly die i would have a Catholic funeral instead of a Buddhist funeral and this bothers me. How can i make this announcement easy on them without sounding like a rebel or a show off?"

Please submit questions to my YouTube Channel: http://www.youtube.com/yuttadhammo

and subscribe for updates here:

http://www.youtube.com/subscription_center?add_user=yuttadhammo

snippet.title: How To Meditate Book (PDF)
snippet.description:
Just wanted to let everyone know that I've edited and expanded the subtitles to my How To Meditate videos and turned the product into a PDF booklet that you can download from my weblog, here:

http://www.sirimangalo.org/teachings/how-to-meditate/

The PDF versions can be downloaded directly:

1) for printing on US Letter paper: http://www.sirimangalo.org/files/HTM.pdf (print even pages first, then odd pages).

2) for printing on A4 paper: http://www.sirimangalo.org/files/HTMa5.pdf (print even pages first, then odd pages).

3) for viewing on a computer screen (A5 layout): http://www.sirimangalo.org/files/HTMa5s.pdf

snippet.title: A Meditator's Life
snippet.description:
To ask questions and join our community, please visit http://meditation.sirimangalo.org/

Re-upload of dhammatalk from June 9, 2018.

snippet.title: Ask A Monk: Bodhi Tree, Monk Food, Anger and Smoking

snippet.title: How To Meditate For Children: A Kid's Guide to Peace
snippet.description:
A video on meditation for children.  It's a mixture of meditating on ideas (like cats, dogs, parents, etc.) and meditating on reality (sitting, breath, etc.).

For more information on how to meditate on reality, you can read my booklet that gives more specific instructions:

http://yuttadhammo.sirimangalo.org/articles/how-to-meditate/

NEW: Subtitle file available here:

http://static.sirimangalo.org/kids.sbv.zip

Download the subtitle file and translate it into your own language, then send me a message and I can upload it.

snippet.title: How To Meditate For Children #3: Love
snippet.description:
Third video in a series devoted to teaching children how to meditate.  This video focuses on a popular form of Buddhist meditation, that of loving-kindness or "metta" in Pali.

For more information on this type of meditation, please see:

http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Mett%C4%81
http://www.accesstoinsight.org/lib/authors/buddharakkhita/wheel365.html

snippet.title: How To Meditate I - What is Meditation
snippet.description: First (of six) in a series of videos on how to practice meditation without the requirement of religious dogma or spiritual mumbo-jumbo.  This video discusses both the meaning of meditation and the foundations of meditation practice.

snippet.title: How To Meditate II - Sitting Meditation
snippet.description: Second (of six) in a series of videos on how to practice meditation without the requirement of religious dogma or spiritual mumbo-jumbo.  This video discusses a simple technique of sitting meditation.

snippet.title: How To Meditate III - Walking Meditation
snippet.description: Third (of six) in a series of videos on how to practice meditation without the requirement of religious dogma or spiritual mumbo-jumbo.  This video demonstrates a simple technique of walking meditation.

snippet.title: How To Meditate IV - Fundamentals of Meditation Practice
snippet.description: Fourth (of six) in a series of videos on how to practice meditation without the requirement of religious dogma or spiritual mumbo-jumbo.  This video discusses some fundamental qualities that are essential to the meditation practice.

snippet.title: How To Meditate V - Mindful Prostration
snippet.description: how to practice meditation without the requirement of religious dogma or spiritual mumbo-jumbo.  This video demonstrates the technique of mindful prostration, a sort of warm-up exercise before the walking and sitting, with the added benefit of creating humility and respect towards the meditation practice.

snippet.title: How To Meditate VI - Meditation Practice and Daily Life
snippet.description: Sixth (of six) in a series of videos on how to practice meditation without the requirement of religious dogma or spiritual mumbo-jumbo.  This video discusses some of the ways to incorporate meditation practice into one's daily life, as well as some of the things that must be moderated or done away with if one expects the meditation to have a real effect on one's daily life.

snippet.title: Questions & Answers 1   How To Meditate
snippet.description:
To ask questions and join our community, please visit http://meditation.sirimangalo.org/
To support our work, please visit http://www.sirimangalo.org/support/

This clip, an addendum to the series on how to meditate, attempts to answer two reoccurring questions in meditation practice; one on the method itself and one on the results to be expected. (orig. publ. 10 Oct 2013)

.

snippet.title: How To Meditate Book (PDF)

Just wanted to let everyone know that I've edited and expanded the subtitles to my How To Meditate videos and turned the product into a PDF booklet that you can download from my weblog, here:

http://www.sirimangalo.org/teachings/how-to-meditate/

The PDF versions can be downloaded directly:

3) for viewing on a computer screen (A5 layout): http://www.sirimangalo.org/files/HTMa5s.pdf

snippet.title: How To Meditate For Children: A Kid's Guide to Peace
snippet.description:
A video on meditation for children.  It's a mixture of meditating on ideas (like cats, dogs, parents, etc.) and meditating on reality (sitting, breath, etc.).

For more information on how to meditate on reality, you can read my booklet that gives more specific instructions:

http://yuttadhammo.sirimangalo.org/articles/how-to-meditate/

NEW: Subtitle file available here:

http://static.sirimangalo.org/kids.sbv.zip

Download the subtitle file and translate it into your own language, then send me a message and I can upload it.
